description: From Old French confit (“preserved fruit”), from Latin cōnfectum. Doublet of confit.

entries.meaning: A confection consisting of a nut, seed or fruit coated with sugar.
examples: "Why, what are they?" she asked, looking at him askance. ¶ "Hashish; did you never hear of it?" ¶ "Oh, yes; it's that Indian stuff which brings one fantastic visions, isn't it? I've always wanted to see and taste it, and now I will," cried Belle, nibbling at one of the bean-shaped comfits with its green heart.

verbs.description: comfit (third-person singular simple present comfits, present participle comfiting, simple past and past participle comfited)

entries.meaning: (transitive, obsolete) To make into a dry sugared confection.
examples: The fruit which does ſo quickly waſte, // Men ſcarce can ſee it, much leſs taſte, // Thou comfiteſt in ſweets to make it laſt.

description: Acronym, from Computer Facial Identification Techniques.

entries.meaning: (Australia) A computerised image of a suspect produced for the police force.
